key_points: Facebook, WhatsApp, and Instagram experienced a six-hour outage on Monday, affecting 2.7 billion global users.
The outage began around 11:30 EST, prompting users and tech leaders to flock to Twitter.
Signal, a private messaging app, gained millions of new users during the outage, with an endorsement from Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey.
Downdetector called the Facebook outage the largest it has ever seen.
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg apologized for the disruption, ensuring services were coming back online.
Instagram head Adam Mosseri acknowledged the challenges faced during the outage.
The outage prevented many Facebook employees from working, likened to a 'snow day' by the company.
Facebook attributed the outage to a 'faulty configuration change' and confirmed no user data was compromised.
Twitter became the primary platform for communication and jokes about the outage, with its official account participating.
The event highlighted the reliance on social platforms for communication and the competitive dynamics between these services.
